thig14.1:1.1.eng: Going to the lovely mango grove

thig14.1:1.3.eng: was held up by a rascal.

thig14.1:2.1.eng: “What harm have I done to you,

thig14.1:2.2.eng: that you stand in my way?

thig14.1:2.3.eng: Good sir, it’s not proper that a man

thig14.1:2.4.eng: should touch a woman gone forth.

thig14.1:3.1.eng: This training was taught by the Holy One,

thig14.1:3.2.eng: it is a serious matter in my teacher’s instructions.

thig14.1:3.3.eng: I am pure and rid of blemishes,

thig14.1:3.4.eng: so why do you stand in my way?

thig14.1:4.1.eng: One whose mind is sullied against one unsullied;

thig14.1:4.2.eng: one who is lustful against one free of lust;

thig14.1:4.3.eng: unblemished, my heart is freed in every respect,

thig14.1:4.4.eng: so why do you stand in my way?”

thig14.1:5.2.eng: what will going-forth do for you?

thig14.1:5.4.eng: come and play in the blossom grove.

thig14.1:6.1.eng: Everywhere, the scent of pollen wafts sweet,

thig14.1:6.3.eng: The start of spring is a happy time—

thig14.1:6.4.eng: come and play in the blossom grove.

thig14.1:7.2.eng: cry out, as it were, in the gale.

thig14.1:7.3.eng: But what kind of fun will you have

thig14.1:7.4.eng: if you plunge into the woods all alone?

thig14.1:8.2.eng: and cow elephants aroused by rutting bulls;

thig14.1:8.3.eng: you wish to go without a friend

thig14.1:9.1.eng: Like a doll made of glittering gold,
thig14.1:9.1.comm: Arthaśastra 2.13.51 describes how to alloy the tapanīya (“glittering gold”) that is ready to be worked.

thig14.1:9.2.eng: like a nymph wandering in a park of colorful vines,

thig14.1:9.4.eng: in graceful clothes of delicate Kāsian cloth.

thig14.1:10.2.eng: if we are to stay in the forest.

thig14.1:10.3.eng: I love no creature more than you,

thig14.1:10.4.eng: O pixie with such captivating eyes.
thig14.1:10.4.comm: “Pixie” is kinnarī, this marking the only appearance of these charming woodland sprites in early Pali; but see the synonymous kiṁpurisa at AN 2.60:1.1. They share with the gandhabba the attributes of being divine musicians, sometimes half-horse (or later, half-bird), and being sensual lovers; but where the gandhabba is associated with licentiousness, the kinnara and kinnarī live together as a perfect dyad of lovers, ever entranced with one another. They are spirits of nature, hidden in the mountains, and threatened by human encroachment (Ja 485). Occasionally, however, a human tribe in the mountains of Kashmir is called Kinnara (= Kinnaur district of Himachal Pradesh?). | The beauty of the pixie’s eyes are praised at Ja 458:1.3, while the phrase “captivating eyes” (mandalocana) is used of a divine maiden at DN 21:1.5.26.

thig14.1:11.1.eng: Were you to take up my invitation—

thig14.1:11.2.eng: ‘Come, be happy, and live in a house’—

thig14.1:11.3.eng: you’ll stay in a longhouse sheltered from wind;

thig14.1:11.4.eng: let the ladies look to your needs.

thig14.1:12.2.eng: put on your garlands and your cosmetics.

thig14.1:12.3.eng: I’ll make all sorts of adornments for you,

thig14.1:12.4.eng: of lustrous gold and gems and pearls.

thig14.1:13.2.eng: its coverlet so clean and nice,

thig14.1:14.1.eng: As a blue lily risen from the water

thig14.1:14.3.eng: so too, O chaste and holy lady,

thig14.1:15.1.eng: “This carcass is full of putrefaction, it swells

thig14.1:15.2.eng: the charnel ground, for its nature is to fall apart.

thig14.1:15.3.eng: What do you think is so essential in it

thig14.1:15.4.eng: that you stare at me so crazily?”

thig14.1:16.1.eng: “Your eyes are like those of a doe,

thig14.1:16.2.eng: or a pixie in the mountains;

thig14.1:16.4.eng: swells in me all the more.

thig14.1:17.1.eng: Your eyes are like a blue lily’s bud

thig14.1:17.2.eng: in your flawless face <j>shining like coruscant gold.
thig14.1:17.2.comm: For “coruscant” (hāṭaka) gold, see AN 3.70:38.4.

thig14.1:17.4.eng: swells in me all the more.

thig14.1:18.1.eng: Though you may wander far, I’ll still think of you,

thig14.1:18.2.eng: with lashes so long and eyes so bright.
thig14.1:18.2.comm: The dassane (plural) are seen by him, so they must be the “eyes”. | In this poem, the English word “eye” must serve for five Pali words: cakkhu, locana, akkhi, and dassana are all from roots of “seeing”, while nayana is from the root sense “leading”.

thig14.1:18.3.eng: I love no eyes more than yours,

thig14.1:18.4.eng: O pixie with such bashful eyes.”

thig14.1:19.1.eng: “You’re setting out on the wrong road!

thig14.1:19.2.eng: You’re looking to take the moon for your toy!

thig14.1:19.3.eng: You’re trying to leap over Mount Meru!

thig14.1:19.4.eng: You, who are hunting a child of the Buddha!

thig14.1:20.1.eng: For in this world with all its gods,

thig14.1:20.2.eng: there will be no more lust anywhere in me.

thig14.1:20.3.eng: I don’t even know what kind it could be,

thig14.1:20.4.eng: it’s been smashed root and all by the path.

thig14.1:21.1.eng: Cast out like sparks from fiery coals,

thig14.1:21.2.eng: it’s worth no more than a bowl of poison.

thig14.1:21.3.eng: I don’t even see what kind it could be,

thig14.1:21.4.eng: it’s been smashed root and all by the path.

thig14.1:22.1.eng: Well may you try to seduce the type of lady

thig14.1:22.2.eng: who has not reflected on these things,

thig14.1:22.3.eng: or who has never attended the Teacher:

thig14.1:22.4.eng: but this is a lady who knows—now you’re in trouble!

thig14.1:23.1.eng: No matter if I am reviled or praised,

thig14.1:23.2.eng: or feel pleasure or pain: I stay mindful.

thig14.1:24.1.eng: I am a disciple of the Holy One,

thig14.1:24.2.eng: riding in the carriage of the eightfold path.

thig14.1:24.3.eng: The dart pulled out, free of defilements,

thig14.1:24.4.eng: I’m happy to have reached an empty place.

thig14.1:25.4.eng: and made to dance in many ways.

thig14.1:26.1.eng: But when the sticks and strings are taken off—

thig14.1:26.4.eng: on what could the mind be fixed?

thig14.1:27.1.eng: That’s what my body is really like,

thig14.1:27.2.eng: without those things it can’t go on.

thig14.1:27.4.eng: on what could the mind be fixed?

thig14.1:28.1.eng: It’s like when you saw a mural made

thig14.1:28.2.eng: by painting yellow on a wall,

thig14.1:28.3.eng: and your vision was deceived by that—

thig14.1:29.1.eng: Like an illusion cast before you,

thig14.1:29.2.eng: or a golden tree in a dream,

thig14.1:29.3.eng: you chase what is hollow, blind one,

thig14.1:29.4.eng: like a painted doll among the people.

thig14.1:30.1.eng: Like a ball in a socket,

thig14.1:30.2.eng: with a pupil in the middle, and tears,

thig14.1:30.3.eng: and mucus comes from there as well,

thig14.1:31.1.eng: Having plucked it out, the fair-eyed lady
thig14.1:31.1.comm: For cārudassanā, compare Sanskrit cārulocanā, “she whose eyes are fair”. Thig 14.1:18.2 above has already established the sense “eye” for dassana.

thig14.1:31.2.comm: For pajjittha, compare Sanskrit apādi, “fall into ruin”.

thig14.1:31.4.eng: she said, and gave it to the man right then.

thig14.1:32.1.eng: And right then he lost his lust,

thig14.1:32.3.eng: “May you be well, O chaste and holy lady;

thig14.1:32.4.eng: such a thing will not happen again.

thig14.1:33.1.eng: Attacking a person such as this

thig14.1:33.2.eng: is like holding on to a blazing fire,

thig14.1:33.4.pli: Api nu sotthi siyā khamehi no”.
thig14.1:33.4.eng: May you be well, please forgive me.”

thig14.1:34.2.eng: she went to the presence of the excellent Buddha.

thig14.1:34.3.eng: Seeing the one with excellent marks of merit,

thig14.1:34.4.eng: her eye became just as it was before.
